title: 109_hr4122
content: The "Comprehensive Entitlement Reform Commission Act of 2005" establishes a Commission to reform entitlement programs like Medicaid, Medicare, and Social Security. The Comprehensive Entitlement Reform Commission is established to review and make recommendations for the sustainability of Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid for future generations. The Commission is tasked with conducting a review of Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid and submitting a final report to Congress and the President within one year. The report will contain recommendations, findings, and conclusions and will be made available to the public. The Commission, composed of 8 members appointed by Senate and House leaders, prohibits Members of Congress or other government officials. Each member serves for the Commission's duration, with vacancies filled in the same manner. Members of the Commission shall be appointed not later than 30 days after the date of enactment of this Act. The Commission shall develop a schedule for completion of the review and report within 60 days of enactment. Two Co-Chairpersons will be selected from among its members, and the Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the required report. SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATION. The Commission shall meet with a quorum of five members for voting purposes, but a quorum is not required for meetings and hearings. Meetings are called by Co-Chairpersons or a majority of members and are generally open to the public. The Commission may hold hearings and conduct necessary activities. Members receive travel expenses as per regulations. Staff support is provided. The Commission is supported by an Executive Director who can appoint staff and procure services as needed. Government employees can be detailed to assist the Commission upon request. The Commission can request personnel from other agencies to assist in its duties without affecting their civil service status. It also has access to necessary resources and information from various government entities. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2006 is set at $1,500,000 under this Act, with funds remaining available without time limit until expended.
